segments.text: then at Scripps, and then went back to Rhode Island.
But he's been very active in the kind of political aspects of these things and so on, and you certainly ought to have a talk with him now.
research vessels.
Obviously you don't have any when you come here.
What do you do?
How do you go about it?
What kind do you try to choose?
What do you want your undergraduates to have?
Just tell me about it.
Well, here we were influenced a good deal by also local tradition and so on.
And when I
arrived here in 51, the department under primarily under Dr. Barnes's I think impetus had obtained through sort of government surplus a small vessel that had been originally built by
the Bureau of Commercial Fisheries.

She was about 115 feet long, wood hull, and had been designed not as a fishing vessel, but essentially as a small kind of passenger and freight vessel to take care of supplying fisheries programs up in Alaska and so on.

She had an interesting sort of characteristic that she could accommodate, although she was a small vessel, she could accommodate quite a large number of passengers and had a large hold which in effect we were able to convert to a sort of laboratory.
She was not, didn't have a great deal of deck space and so on.
But this vessel had been procured, and it required a certain amount of conversion, as they always do, and also the installation of necessary winches and so on.
We used this what was, in a sense, a very small type vessel up until we obtained the
the Thompson, which is one of these Agars, in about 1965 or 66.
So we used Brown Bear for about 15 years, and not only for local work inside Puget Sound and so on and off the coast, but we took her out into the North Pacific.
not but she was range limited as well as so size limited and so it was sort of gulf of alaska and so on but out along the illusion chain and in 1964 and i'm sorry 19 must be 19
1959, 1960, we actually took her north up into the Bering Sea and actually into the Arctic.
So we extended, we stretched her capabilities just about as much
and maybe beyond sort of reasonable limits.
But she proved to be a very kind of efficient vessel in that she could be operated with a fairly small crew and so on.
And we thought we got a lot of good work out of her.
When she was replaced by the T.G.
Thompson, we were

We were clearly thought of vessel limited, but we ended up with a real sort of problem here in the fact that we were really rather reluctant to take on one of these AGARs, but had been told repeatedly by ONR and NSF that the vessel would be completely funded.
because it was almost an order of magnitude jump here in the cost of operations and so on.
So we finally did, and of course we no sooner had delivery of the ship than they said they couldn't budget it.
And the department has really been fighting ever since to, in a sense, get adequate vessels, operation support for the vessels.

And one thing we did not get involved in, and it was done intentionally, and maybe hard to tell whether we were right or wrong, but we never got involved in anything like the Indian Ocean Expedition, or even going back prior to that to the IGY of
using this as a mechanism, in a sense, to expand the fleet and so on, which was clearly done, I think, at some of the institutions.
They used these major national
efforts to increase the size of their fleet.

But we've never felt we had quite the same, or I never felt, maybe I should say, and I know some of the faculty would agree with me, that we should try and do the same kind of things as Scripps and Woods Hole did.
But we had our own destiny to try and work out here, which didn't necessarily involve the very extensive sea-going cruises.
Did you expect all your undergraduates to work on the vessel out at sea?
Oh, I think I would have said yes if you go back to the early 50s or something, but we got very much caught up with this.
The Sputnik era here, with increased interest in science and so on.
And certainly the ocean became a very romantic sort of an area of study.
And so our undergraduate program shot up at a rate that I don't think we would ever have sort of predicted.
And we were, our undergraduate enrollment in oceanography was increasing about 25% a year, which means it doubled every three years.
And we went from one student or something in 1952, and we were up to I think over 800 in
Well, the early 60s, I guess it was.

And, I mean, it was clearly obvious you couldn't do the kind of things that we'd originally had in mind, which, as I think I mentioned earlier, a really sort of practical preparation of sea work and so forth.
And it got to a point that

We couldn't even give laboratories with our formal courses because we didn't have the capacity to handle this number of students, so even the kind of laboratory work clearly suffered under this expansion.
It was very exciting, but
I think, probably went too far.
Now, I don't know what the later, what's happening in the last year or two, but it's dropped down considerably, the undergraduate enrollment.
But it, in a sense, got overinflated here, but not really due to our recruiting efforts or anything, but just because of the general

And we've done a lot of things other than just the sort of formal undergraduate and graduate training here, in that it started back in the days where I really felt we did need to provide some input of students and so on.
which involved working with high school teachers and so on.
I ran summer institutes for high school teachers for a number of years here, with the idea that they'd encourage some of their students to come into the field.
I've been involved in the writing of two high school level textbooks.
So we did that, and one of the things which had started before the war was a general sort of introductory oceanography course which still carries them.
number of Oceanography 101, which was in no way intended for our own majors, but a science orientation course.
And most of the students who take it are not even science students, but humanities and social science students.
We were teaching.
That's a five-credit course.
And a few years ago, at least, we were teaching that to over 1,500 students a year.
We build up, certainly.
I must have some sort of general public awareness of the field, at least.
And I think these are worthwhile things.
They're not just sort of promotional.
But anybody living around here, I think, ought to know a little bit about what the ocean is like.
So that's still going on.
When you started to outfit these early vessels, did you have a professional captain do something?
Something like James Spahn, I'm thinking of, or did you try to do it within your department?
No, we started out in a sort of small way here, and the first man we had who was skipper of, he'd been a skipper of an even smaller vessel before the Brown Bear, had
no sort of formal training as an officer.
He had been a fisherman primarily, and a small boat operator type person, and came in and kind of learned the job as he went along.
He was a marvelous individual, and Frank Princehouse, and very much interested in the
in what we were trying to do, and extremely cooperative and very good at taking care of the vessel and the crew and so on.
We actually had to see that he got the opportunity to get some sort of special training and so on when the Thompson came along, because otherwise he couldn't have been captain on the Thompson.
Unfortunately, shortly after we got the Thompson, he developed a serious
Elmont and since died, but he was captain on her for about a year or so.
And then we went to these more sort of professionally trained officers.
And I think the man that's captain now is the Thompson that came to us from Scripps, having been on one of their ships.
So there's been a switch there, but it's partly
related again just to the size of the vessels and the kind of Coast Guard regulations about the types of officers that you have to have on board.
When you first come to Washington, the funding for oceanography and oceanographic departments was sort of a block funding.
That is, that...
When I came out here.
When you came out here, right.
Yes.
Is that ONR and so forth would give sort of a block funding to a university, which has moved recently to sort of special project fundings.
What sort of feeling do you have about that as it affects the way you try to work your department?
Well, of course, I've been out of this, you know, for about ten years.
But I just think it's been a very unfortunate sort of trend.
And I keep hoping I can see some sign that's going to reverse itself.
But I don't think I have been able to see anything so far that, yes, although the
In a sense, in terms of the total dollars, they were small now compared to what's being transferred these days.
Nevertheless, they were relatively large amounts, and in the first few years when essentially all our support came from ONR, it almost used to be done by letter.
they'd send us a letter saying, what do you want to do?
And we'd write a letter back saying, we think it'd be fun to do so.
And they'd say, well, we think we can give you X thousand dollars next year.
And why don't you write a request for that?
And we'd write another letter saying, we'd like to have so much for next year.
And that was it.
But since then, it has gone progressively towards more agencies involved, which
in a way, is life insurance, I think, from our point of view, because not all of them go up and down at the same time, so it gives you some sort of security in that way.
But the fact that the projects have been split down and down and down and down, and two,
the situation which I feel prevails today where money is not allocated really to, although legally it comes to the university and to the department, it's based on these individual sort of proposals.
And what people do is start talking about my money and my ship time and so forth.
I think that from an administrative point of view it's essentially an intolerable situation and that the chairman of the department has no way of administering.
All he's doing is trying to fit together all these little bits and pieces and he has no way of fitting things together in most cases.
and saying, okay, you two fellows get together, use the ship jointly or something.
They both say, well, I got my money to do so and so on.
And it's completely sort of ridiculous.
I think it's a part of sort of Parkinson's law here that this is the way in which a bureaucracy functions.
It tends to generate work for itself, and this is exactly what I can see is happening in Washington, that
If you can have 100 projects under your guidance, rather than 10, you've got that much more paper, and you justify many more positions, and so on.
But this, plus the fact that there are many, many more sort of bookkeeping requirements these days than there used to be, really makes it
major sort of problem, I think, from the administrative point of view, to do these things.
The problem, I think, has sort of been compounded recently by the fact that they've got into this multi-institutional
pattern here and I haven't had any direct part of any of these things because I don't know how they manage to do those things and keep them going.
But even the Sea Grant program was originally thought of as a sort of block funding type thing and even there they
without any kind of appropriate authorization from Congress or anything, they went off in the same direction of breaking things down into ridiculously small things.
And there's all the paperwork involved with this, as well as the lack of flexibility.
The other thing that's been happening here is the fact that you're committed
to making plans longer and longer in advance that you want any kind of major support these days.
You've probably got a plan about three years ahead and hard to get it.
The result is, by the time this third year's rolled around, you have absolutely no flexibility.
If things have changed or something, you're kind of stuck with things.
So that planning is fine, but certainly you lose any kind of choice in things.
A lot of the problems that have come from the combination of inflation and reduced funding and so on have really been most critical since I stepped aside as chairman of the department.
And I thought I was leaving everything and looked rosy at the time that I decided that I would step down as chairman.
And I couldn't, in a sense, I probably couldn't have chosen a better time.
But I certainly had no anticipation of what was going to happen.
What about the division of agencies, which you mentioned earlier?
Let me sketch something for you.
ONR becomes more mission-oriented as it advances upward after World War II, let's say particularly after 1949.
And you begin to have the rise of NSF and other scientific agencies to administer oceanography.
Was this essentially a good thing?
Well, the...
I think it was for probably many different sort of reasons.
But ONR was obviously strictly a Navy type thing, although in the early days they certainly interpreted their responsibilities very broadly, I think, relatively speaking.
But there were areas that they were sort of not touching at all.
But essentially, at least my interpretation is that sort of out of the ONR model came this idea for NSF.
And NSF was set up, as I recall, in 1951.
Let's see, the first director was moved over from ONR, remember, wasn't it?
Waterman.
But the general situation was that ONR would continue to support oceanography.
NSF would get into, essentially, other fields.
And NSF really didn't get into oceanography to any, I think I'm right in saying, any kind of significant extent until the IGYCAPE program came along, which was actually in
what was it, 57, 58, but where the funding must have predated that by a year or so.

And I think NSF picked that up because, well, it was not just oceanography, there were many other aspects, but it would not have been appropriate for ONR to have gone into all of these other fields besides oceanography, certainly some of them.
So this is really what moved NSF into the picture, and they've essentially never been out of it since.
And the sort of drift of things has been such that we've been told various times, well, NSF's going to pick up more and more of this.
I don't know quite what has happened.
ONR seemed to be sort of going down in level of support as far as they were concerned here, but now I hear that maybe they're coming up again and so on.
What has been difficult is for us, and we're not alone in this,
is to how do you sort of deal with ONR, NSF, AEC, which no longer exists under that name, but how do you keep some sort of a balance or whatever with these different agencies?
And very often I feel that we have been in the position of kind of divide and conquer.
where all the money and so forth existed in Washington.
They were the ones who got together and decided, well, we'll support this institution to such and such a level.
We're put in a position of asking people for
in a sense, overlapping kind of support.
I don't think this is actually done.
But I mean, you never know quite what's going to come out of these things.
So I think it's been kind of a scary game here.
And AEC turned out to be a fairly substantial supporter for our work here, and entirely on sort of environmental studies, although they were related to
to essentially radioactive materials that might get into the Columbia River and so on.
So that was a concern to them, but they were a kind of major supporter here.

It seems almost to an outsider that it's as if oceanographers looked at what the government wanted and planned a research topic they might get funded rather than moving out and directing research to what interested them.
Is that a?

I think so, and of course there's always the kind of argument here about freedom of research and so forth, and I think all of the agencies have made quite a conscious effort to play fair on this thing, but the fact is that they do
influence you a good deal, not by telling you what to do, but by refusing to support things that they didn't want to do.
So things do become very much controlled in this way, and exceedingly difficult to get sort of new things started, and particularly to get sort of younger men started and so on here.
So I think it reached a point where there was a sort of undesirable amount of control over what goes on.
Sure, you do things where the money is.
Now, we've chosen in a few cases not to go where the money was.
We didn't participate at all in this Indian Ocean expedition by choice.
We did not, we were asked at one time if we wanted to get involved in a lot of the Antarctic operations, and we said no thank you, we didn't want to.
We've, I guess, here have operated a little bit more on a sort of an individual basis than some, and have not participated maybe as much in some of these
multi-institutional programs that have been coming along here in recent years.
Some of the individuals have.
They've participated and gone on and so on.
Now, we did get quite involved here for several years in this as part of the international, what's it called, international biological program on this upwelling.
But we've more or less operated more by ourselves, in a way.
Is this because of the undergraduate emphasis here?
No, I don't think one could say that, although the good many

of the faculty are involved in teaching, either at undergraduate or graduate level, which means that they're not entirely free to go off for long periods without making appropriate sort of adjustments and reallocations.
No, I think it's more sort of individual choices.
I may be overemphasizing this in a way,

One thing that I sort of fought against for a number of years was getting involved in this general sort of marine geophysics, this refraction and reflection, seismic shooting and so on, which involved carrying
explosives and was, in a sense, kind of a hazardous thing.
And I said, I didn't think we ought to get into that.
There were two or three institutions that were heavily involved in it.
Why did we have to get into it?
Well, lo and behold, some money came along, and we were doing it.
And we no sooner got started on it than ONR cut off the support.
So we were probably being well advised never to get
really sort of committed to that thing.
And I think there have been some, probably some similar sort of things.
So it's, I think if one took a really sort of objective view of things, one would find that
The programs in this country are pretty much sort of what the federal government agencies want them to be.
There's very little sort of independence here now.
They can always turn around and say that anybody who wants to can submit a proposal on anything they think they want to do.
If something isn't going on, it's because nobody's interested in doing the work.
So they're kind of stuck on this.
I, just for fun here several years ago, I dreamed up a rhetorical question.
I asked Professor Rattray whether I could have the Thompson for a couple of weeks.
And he said, what do you want the Thompson for?
And I said, I'm not going to tell you, but I've got an idea that I want to test.
Can I have the ship for a couple of weeks?
And he thought for a while, and he said, well, he guessed I could.
It would require some telephoning to Washington to get some funds reallocated and so on.
But if I really had a good thing, I could probably get the ship.
And I said, what about some people to help me?
And he said, oh, no, no people.
Everybody's committed, you see, to other programs.
So I had, this was just,
hypothetical question, but it indicates how tied up you are with the system in a way.
We had a, we've mentioned it at lunchtime here, we had this drought situation this year, and it was more than just a local drought, something very unusual has been happening out in the
